paragraphs:
[1]
Rouleau, J.
: This is an application for judicial review of a decision by an immigration officer dated July 29, 1993, wherein it was determined that there were insufficient humanitarian and compassionate grounds to warrant processing his application for permanent residence from within Canada.

[2]
The applicant, a citizen of Trinidad, arrived in Canada on June 18, 1988, and claimed Convention refugee status. He was eventually joined in Canada by his wife and two sons. On October 23, 1992, it was determined that there was no credible basis to his claim; a "back end" humanitarian and compassionate review determined that there were no exceptional circumstances so as to warrant the exercise of the Governor-in-Council's discretion for processing from within Canada, and a departure notice was issued on December 12, 1993.

[3]
On May 14, 1993, the applicant made yet another request for reconsideration on humanitarian and compassionate grounds. He states that he has been steadily employed in Canada since November 1989 and together with his wife, they earn approximately $40,000 per annum. They have purchased a car, household furnishings and they have approximately $10,000 in savings. They have established roots in the community; both boys attend school, they attend the Hindu temple in Pickering on a regular basis and he volunteers his spare time to the care of an elderly disabled gentleman. They regard Canada as their home and if permitted to stay, he intends to establish his own electrical business. They have no home or assets in Trinidad and if forced to leave, it is highly unlikely that he could find employment while waiting for his application for permanent residence to be processed. He believes that, having due regard to their emotional and economic establishment in Canada; the hardship that would be caused if he has to leave Canada warrants favourable consideration.

[4]
Counsel on behalf of the applicant submitted that in deciding as he did the immigration officer breached the duty of fairness owed to the applicant insofar as the applicant was not interviewed nor was he given an opportunity to respond to any concerns that the officer might have had with respect to his application. Additionally, he was not provided with reasons for this negative decision thereby depriving him of any means of determining what factors were considered in his case and whether or not they were properly considered:
 <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  C.C.C.(2d) 353; 106 D.L.R.(3d) 385; 13 C.R.(3d) 1;
H.K. (an infant), Re
, [1967] 1 All E.R. 226 (D.C.), and
 <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  (T.D.).

[5]
I am satisfied that the rules of natural justice were not breached; the record indicates that this was the fourth time that the applicant's file had been considered for exemption under s. 114(2) of the
Immigration Act
(the
Act
); that he had been personally interviewed on earlier occasions and that he was aware of the reasons for these negative decisions. Furthermore, this court has held that in circumstances such as the present, there is no obligation under s. 114(2) to conduct an interview nor is there a duty to provide reasons:
 <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  (T.D.). I am mindful of the fact that this unfavourable decision takes no right away from the applicant, it simply requires him to abide by the requirements of s. 9(1) of the
Act
and apply for permanent residence from a visa officer abroad.

[6]
This application is dismissed.
Application dismissed.
Editor: Angela E. McKay/nmg
[End of document]

legal_issues: Whether a procedural fairness obligation exists to conduct an interview in the context of discretionary immigration decisions.
Whether a duty exists to provide reasons for a negative discretionary immigration decision.
The scope of discretion afforded to immigration officials in determining applications for permanent residence based on humanitarian and compassionate grounds.
The standard of review applicable to immigration decisions concerning humanitarian and compassionate considerations.
factual_background: An individual, a citizen of Trinidad, arrived in Canada on June 18, 1988, and claimed refugee status.
The individual was later joined in Canada by his wife and two sons.
A claim for refugee status was deemed to have no credible basis on October 23, 1992.
A humanitarian and compassionate review determined there were no exceptional circumstances to process the application for permanent residence from within Canada.
A departure notice was issued on December 12, 1993.
A request for reconsideration based on humanitarian and compassionate grounds was made on May 14, 1993.
The applicant had been steadily employed in Canada since November 1989, earning approximately $40,000 annually with his wife.
The applicant and his wife had accumulated savings of approximately $10,000 and purchased a car and household furnishings.
The couple's children were attending school in Canada.
The family regularly attended a Hindu temple and the applicant volunteered with an elderly disabled individual.
The applicant stated he intended to establish an electrical business in Canada.
The applicant reported having no assets or home in Trinidad and anticipated difficulty finding employment while awaiting processing of a permanent residence application from abroad.

Applicants: The immigration officer breached the duty of fairness by not interviewing the applicant.
The applicant was not given an opportunity to respond to any concerns the officer might have had regarding his application.
The applicant was not provided with reasons for the negative decision, preventing him from understanding the factors considered.
The hardship of leaving Canada, considering their emotional and economic establishment, warrants favourable consideration of their case.
They have established roots in Canada through employment, savings, community involvement (school, temple, volunteering), and intend to establish a business.
They have no assets or prospects in Trinidad and would likely be unable to find employment while awaiting processing of a permanent residence application from abroad.
Respondents: The applicant had been previously interviewed on multiple occasions.
The applicant was aware of the reasons for previous negative decisions.
There is no obligation under s. 114(2) of the Immigration Act to conduct an interview in these circumstances.
There is no duty to provide reasons for the decision.

court_analysis: The court found no breach of natural justice occurred in the immigration officer's decision. This conclusion was based on the fact that the applicant had been previously interviewed on multiple occasions regarding his claim and was aware of the reasons for prior negative decisions.

The court relied on precedent establishing that section 114(2) of the Immigration Act does not mandate an interview or the provision of reasons for a negative decision in cases like this one, where the applicant is seeking an exemption to standard procedures.

The court distinguished the decision as not removing any existing rights from the applicant, but rather requiring him to follow the standard process outlined in section 9(1) of the Act – applying for permanent residence through a visa officer abroad.

The court determined that the repeated consideration of the applicant’s file (this being the fourth review) and his prior interviews satisfied any procedural fairness requirements, despite the lack of a new interview or detailed reasons for the latest denial.
